row.Text: One caveat: my understanding (from talking to my wife, who is a healthcare professional) is that just *testing* (even if it's negative) might be a red flag for your health insurance, and reason for them to drive up your rates. So if you can get it done privately (so they would not know about it) that might be advisable.

@ClayNichols Good point. [Planned Parenthood](http://www.plannedparenthood.org/health-topics/stds-hiv-safer-sex/std-testing-21695.asp) offers testing services (often with a sliding fee scale), and there are also many over-the-counter tests available for various STIs/STDs with varying price ranges. If you opt for an over-the-counter test be sure to do a little research first: You want a test with a reasonably high sensitivity, and ideally a high specificity as well (and obviously follow up with your doctor if you receive a positive result on a home test!).
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G-Spot has a chart. (Is this question general reference?)
Wikipedia's got an extensive [list](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homosexual_behavior_in_animals).
*n.b.* Female homosexual couples also take part in this practice, as well as other combinations of genders and sexualities.
Note that sodomy is not limited to acts involving the anus.

Finding the right place is actually not that difficult, as for the G-spot it's a rough area, easiest felt when the receiver is aroused, about a half to one finger length inside the vagina towards their front (stand face to face, insert a finger and make a come-hither motion with the finger). The prostate is similarly placed in the rectum, only further in and should feel a bit spongy but firm, if it's hard or rough you should go see a doctor yesterday.

These sites don't generally allow questions of general reference. "Where's my g-spot" is an oft asked question on most discussion sites, but much like asking where your [Metacarpus is](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metacarpus), a quick look-up of ["G-Spot" on Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gspot) provides a diagram pointing to its reported location. That's what makes it "general reference."
This site is explicitly about *human* sexuality. Questions about broader issues of sexuality in nature were not part of the scope of this site.
This is a way too generic question to really be answered here, erectile dysfunction can have number of different causes and should be treated such as.

I have to agree. The causes of and cures for ED range from the psychological to the physical, including genetics, diseases, medications, drugs, surgery, etc. These sites work much better when asking very specific questions about specific problems to solve. As asked, this questions is not easily answered in this format.
I'm not talking about the first time. I mean *every* damn time.

hmmm... If you've ruled out the stuff you've ruled out and it's not a matter of prep work or stretching you may want to consider anaesthetic lubricants (I know they exist, but I can't think of any brand names off-hand)
I can think of some names that should exist but don't. Has-t-fuk? Secret-shag. Lube-o-cain.

@TomO'Connor The Trojan condoms that come pre-greased with the anaesthetic stuff are called "Extended Pleasure" or something similar (I believe they use benzocane as the anaesthetic -- a prescription or OTC benzocane cream may be an option, but I'd check with a doctor about condom compatibility and to ensure the cream won't be "irritating")

This question is about a medical standpoint, not a human sexuality issue. As such, it's off-topic for the site. If you have further questions, please ask in [meta](http://meta.sexuality.stackexchange.com).
Care to summarize (bullet points are fine) in case the blog link ever goes dead? :-)
I've tried to summarise the salient points, but it's really worth a read.
What is "edging"? I'm guessing that's where you come very close to climax and then stop?
Can you cite any sources? These seem to be off-the-cuff, "obvious" responses.
Sorry, added clarification in my answer.
Don't use a microwave.
Fantastic! Thanks.
@TomO'Connor yeh. Ouch :)
@KurtisNusbaum You're welcome, I guess I should've cited things to begin with, rather than go off with "common knowledge".

On other SE sites, we tend to frown on shopping recommendations. I'm unsure whether this one would be any different, but I think that objective, well-written reviews would be a good thing for this site.
No worries. I think citing sources is going to be one of those things that help greatly in keeping this site legitimate. Not to mention it helps make our answers seem more reputable.
Was this not one of the example questions for this stack exchange from the proposal?
@ClayNichols I'm in the UK, what is "health insurance"???? Can you please edit saying "In the USA, ..." Since health insurance, may not apply to everyone who can read this site.
Sex at Dawn (http://www.sexatdawn.com/) further suggests that birth control pills affects who a woman is attracted to (what character traits, etc.).
See also: http://sexuality.stackexchange.com/questions/18/why-does-anal-sex-hurt
See also http://sexuality.stackexchange.com/questions/7/why-is-anal-sex-pleasurable
A variant may be on-topic, such as "How does male circumcision affect sexual experience?"
Is the context here "how can a woman hide her orgasm?" or "how to tell if a woman is faking an orgasm?" or something else?
Probably the first would be closer, although both can be explored and explained.

Not only was this was an example question on the proposal, it was in fact the *top-voted* example question. Voting to reopen on that basis alone. http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/3303?phase=definition
Isn't this a bit too basic for a site for experts?

I've made an edit (currently pending) that cleans this up & makes it more obviously on topic -- Hopefully one of the pro-tem mods (@Aarthi ? :) can pick it up & approve it/reopen (and also clean up the comments).
Just as a data point: mainstream porn stars in the USA typically get tested monthly. Reference: http://www.cnn.com/2011/HEALTH/05/19/std.protection.ep/index.html

While we don't typically allow "general reference" questions that can be answered by a 30-second Google this question is the Human Sexuality analog to [How does subnetting work](http://serverfault.com/questions/49765/how-does-subnetting-work) on ServerFault: If we ***don't*** have an answer this question will be asked by a new user every day. Voting to reopen so we can have a canonical answer.

@Hobblin Excellent locating guide (if/when we get the [G-Spot](http://sexuality.stackexchange.com/questions/5/where-is-the-popular-g-point) question reopened you should add the female part as an answer there!) -- Re: locating the prostate, I've found it's much easier to find on someone else than on myself (and conversely it's easier for other guys to find mine). That could just be me though :)
There are other excellent benefits to Kegel exercises (for both men and women) -- Highly recommended even if you *aren't* looking for a way to control premature ejaculation.

Unfortunately I can't offer much advice on the erectile dysfunction aspect - I've got a few friends on various psych meds with similar woes. Best advice I can give there is speak to your doctor about erectile dysfunction treatments that are compatible with your other meds.

@TomO'Connor I have mixed feelings about using this site for "reviews", though I certainly don't mind if people give advice on how to use/maximize pleasure from toys as part of an answer. Might be a good topic for a meta discussion...

@voretag7 Thank you, yes that might also be interesting to mention... both when it comes to the G-spot but more so when it comes to the prostate it can be hard for oneself to get at it comfortably because of how the arm needs to bend. Hard G-spot, and I assume prostate, stimulation is best performed by someone else.

I'm against using this site for reviews and I also think that this is off-topic since it really has nothing to do with human sexuality but rather about customer satisfaction, so I'm voting to close this one.
Depends what it is. Some things are blatently unsuitable, IMO. Having sex in a box at Symphony Hall is asking for trouble.

I would really like you to better document the claims of (1) connection between fandom and autism/asperger and (2) connection between autims/asperger and "alternative sexuallity". Because as for now, your answer is completely undocumented (that's why I minus it).

You might consider editing this question to be more specific about *which* spermicide. I think most people think of nonoxynol-9 when they think of spermicide, but there are lots of others and the answers might vary for each.

One might ask what the *sexual* benefits of circumcision are (another question). But "why people should get circumcised" is largely medical/cultural/religious. But since folks looking for that information might expect it to be here, I'll join the re-open voters and re-open this revised question as sort of an isolated issue.

Thank you for the contribution, but this doesn't answer the question. It just avoids the issue with alternatives. The discussion of alternatives might be interesting for a discussion board or a chat room, but in this type of Q&A we're looking for *the* canonical answer to the question asked. Sorry for the down-vote. It's nothing personal; this particular answer just misses the mark.

The problem with listing review sites, or shopping recommendations, or favorite books/blog, etc, etc. is the everyone will just pile in with their pet favorite. Essentially, when everyone can answer and no answer is better than any other, this starts to fall outside the *purpose* of what makes these sites unique and authoritative. It sounds helpful, but it really detracts from core usefulness of the site.
@TomO'Connor hmm, that *would* give a whole new meaning to the "cannon fire" in the 1812 overture, wouldn't it... I'll update my Assumptions block accordingly :-)
Also, linking to review sites doesn't necessarily help future readers coming to our site at a later point. There's no telling whether the site will continue to exist tomorrow.

There is not a straightforward, generally agreed-on answer to this question. A Google search already return a wealth of resources. The Wikipedia article (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circumcision) covers the topic in detail, better than we could hope to do in a Q-and-A format. The poster does not seem to be facing an actual problem.
It kind of sounds like you're asking what the emergency contraceptive pill *is* - which seems like a far too basic question for an SE site.
let me edit it to change that

I would also add that 'blending in' ('passing' is the term most often used in the community) is not every trans person's goal. There are also people who do not find their identity is accurately represented by either of the more traditional genders and identify as 'genderqueer'. Genderqueer doesn't necessarily mean they identify as a 'third' gender, but rather that their gender identity does not fall into the traditional binary.

I don't have access to real stats but my ad hoc data gathering from friends who have taken it is that it (Plan B specifically) often causes significant menstrual changes for several months. Would love to have that confirmed / denied from an expert though.

Just a note on format-- The crux of your question should be asked first because that is what appears in the preview on the homepage. Ideally, the information in that "'assumptions' banner" should be included in the body of the message, but if you must... it should be posted at the bottom of the post so not to interfere with the normal mechanisms of the site.
@Katey's point is correct. All of this illustrates why the question of 'are there more transwomen than transmen' is so complicated and difficult to answer in a satisfactory way.
Now I've included some quite bad sources, could unfortunately not find a lot of material on the subject.

The 20-25% is from a friend of mine that is going through with sex reassignment surgery in Sweden.
I would also like to point out that the article you mention says that there where 80% transwomen patients and that you probably read the statistics wrong. 31% of the transwomenand 64% of transmen did gender related surgery, the statistics still says there is more transwomen.
@Hobblin Hm. I know basically nothing about the trans community in Sweden. I wonder if there's better statistical data there.

@RobertCartaino good point about the preview. Re: the Assumptions: banner, I'm undecided on whether they're a good idea or not (working it into the body of a post can be wordy for long lists of assumptions, but I agree in principle that it's preferable if the question can incorporate the information rather than making it a separate item).

Could unfortunately not find any data in english but RFSL is the organization fighting for the rights of LGBTQ community in sweden http://www.rfsl.se/?p=2404 , the first pie-chart shows the number of applications for reassignment in Sweden.
Also, **NB:** Another good book about research into human female sexual response is *Bonk* by Mary Roach. Definitely worth a read.
@Hobblin downvote retracted :)

Have you tried talking to your partner about these urges? Communication is almost always good. Who knows, she might even be ok with it. And if she isn't, well now it's out in the open which is certainly better than hiding it.
Voting to close: this is far to geographically specific.
Notably, this is actually *easier* to reach by a partner and not by oneself with a vibrator or dildo; the pressure needed to stimulate the g-spot properly is, anecdotally, hard to apply on oneself.
@Jay: I don't think so. Even if it is fairly basic, it's an important and useful question to ask.
+1 in particular for "knowing ones own body".
Of course it hurts like buggery. It *is* buggery!
@voretaq: In case the link ever goes dead, it's now archived at http://www.webcitation.org/64e4n7tVy.
Not sure `fandom` is the right word for the furry community, but I am not an expert.
There are also studies regarding STD transmission and circumcision such a lowered risk of HIV infection.
Related : http://xkcd.com/400/
@me_and I don't agree. These products are normally sold internationally. A reviews of a toy where the author is in a different country is still relevant.
Ask Freud; he'll tell you civilization is only possible because of sublimation ;)
@AbbyT.Miller I was also considering other names, but since this is how it appeared on Wikipedia, I used that term.

To answer the unasked half of this question: there are medications to counteract the libido-reducing effect of antidepressants and similar drugs. Viagra and its alternatives will have the well-known effects, but there're also drugs that will help counteract any decrease in libido as well as the physical aspect of being able to achieve an erection.
Fair enough. Like I said, I'm no expert.
+1 for sublimation. Never heard that term before but I'm all to familiar with the concept. It's nice to finally have a name for it.
This is a question about gender, not sexuality. They're frequently confused, but entirely different.
+1 very comprehensive.

I'd suggest having a read of [The Ethical Slut](http://www.amazon.co.uk/Ethical-Slut-Infinite-Sexual-Possibilities/dp/1890159018). It may be of no use to you, or it may open up a whole world of ways of dealing with this issue.
Possibly relevant: [Wikipedia on Sexual addiction](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_addiction).
@Kurtis Nusbaum You know, I've been waiting for a chance to pull out that bit of knowledge for years. So this was a very exciting moment in my life.
can you expand on retarded ejaculation? Namely, is it permanent, or does it wear off after the masturbation has been "toned down".

I would probably add that replacing sex with physical exertion, it can be very effective at least it has been for me in periods of my life. Getting a better physical fitness could increase the libido tho so it's a fine balancing act sometimes for it to not become a spiral out of control. Exercise is addictive, especially if it's used to fill some other need.

@Dima: In general, you can find information on terms on websites like Wikipedia. Specifically, by paying a monthly fee to a health insurance company they can pay most of your medical costs. This ensures that you don't have to keep track of this yourself. In the UK, you have the [National Health Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_insurance#United_Kingdom)...
Taking a break or switching up masturbation methods usually set the problem to rights.
This is a really good point that I probably wouldn't have thought of.

Another question about [objective sexual toy review websites](http://sexuality.stackexchange.com/questions/39/objective-sexual-toy-review-websites) was closed. This question asks the same thing but about a specific type of toy.
+1 for actually finding the correct term (Sublimation). Also +1 for Hobblin's suggestion of physical exertion as a substitute.
A much better answer after the rewrite, +1
Any word on storage conditions (the wallet bit)? I've never found a good reliable source saying one way or the other...
**Side note:** [We're discussing when gender questions are on-topic.](http://meta.sexuality.stackexchange.com/questions/29/gender-vs-sexuality)
**Side note:** [We're discussing when gender questions are on-topic.](http://meta.sexuality.stackexchange.com/questions/29/gender-vs-sexuality)

@voretaq7: I haven't either. As they are slightly less efficient/durable I would say that friction would make storage less ideal, I don't know how other environmental impacts like heat would affect the materials. But as a general rule of thumb it's best to never store them in tight wallets and really watch out with loose wallets, just carry them apart...

@Tom Yeah, I saw that. I think that this falls under the "directly related to sexuality" category of questions since I am asking about sexual preference. But I do see how this also has a relationship/society side to it as well though...
Where do you find such partners? They are hard to find around here...

@KurtisNusbaum: I think it is mainly the transition of "what I feel physically from myself" to "what I feel emotionally from this intercourse", that transition is probably harder when you use hands-free forms of masturbation which I won't disclose here but are focused on being even more satisfied...
Gender identiy and sexuality are often improperly associated with each other. While there may be strong *correlations* between the two, one's sexuality is not dictated by one's gender identity.

I sort of regret linking to that fact sheet. It seems very outdated. One of its sources is from 2007; the rest are from *ten years prior*. Seems fishy, and it might be causing more confusion than it's solving!

@Hobblin My point with the statistics from that article was not about the number of transwomen vs transmen - it was about the number of trans people who choose to have surgery. I just wanted to make it clear that not all trans people have surgery, so surgical procedures are not an effective way to count trans people.
P.S.: I don't identify as trans and I make no claims at being an expert. Please feel free to school me if anything above is wrong.
I had figured that this was a person by person thing, but I was still confused by the situation. A very thorough answer, thank you.

I find no reference to them being less efficient in the link. It only says that polyurethane condoms are less stretchy and therefor breaks easier (which is a problem for reliability not efficiency) but the linked answer does not seems to be aware that, for example, the Lifestyles SKYN is made from polyisoprene which is basically synthesizer latex with the same qualities as natural latex only less allergenic.
Just want to point out that Lifestyles Skyn is not made of polyurethane but rather polyisoprene which is synthesized latex, which is what makes it less allergenic.
+1 excellent and very thorough answer.
@Hobblin Thanks for your effort, previous downvote reversed.

Apologies in advance: I had a hard time figuring out a good way to ask this question. I'm open to suggestions for improvement. I also wonder if it's more *Anthropology* than *Sexuality*, and so off-topic for this site.

I think, from a Parenting view, it's normal to conceal sexual expressions to 1) prevent your kids from repeating your actions and 2) delay them questioning about it until they are of the right age. It think it is an universal habit to do this for that reason, pictures depicting such activities where there are children visible are usually referred to as "bad parent(ing/s)". Is it fine that I post this as an answer? Or are you looking for more funded answers? I don't think that there are much studies / thesis on this subject, though...

I would call reliability a part of efficiency; a condom that is obviously not reliable is surely not efficient. While there exist reliable condoms that don't break and are not efficient on the other hand, that's out of the scope here. It does not say that polyisoprene shares the same quality, but rather that it tries to go for the best of both worlds. I'll look into detailing the notion between polyisoprene and polyurethane none-the-less, I have made the stupid assumption to think they are the same as they are at least trying to do the same thing...

I remember a scene in "Dances with Wolves" where the (Native American) parents were having sex in their tipi at night. Tipis only have one room, so the kids were present, and were aware of what was going on. Obviously that's a movie, so I can't vouch for its factual basis; but not all cultures are as afraid to talk about sex as Americans are.

@Tom, it's "normal" *in Western culture* to conceal sexual expressions from children. If you want to claim that it's universal, I'd want to see some citations; after all, cultural assumptions are what this question is all about. The kinds of "harm" we would think of children undergoing from repeating parents' actions might not be as big a deal in some cultures. For example, without our culture's rigid social structures around school and jobs, a teen mother would be just another mother.

@JoeWhite: I'm not drawing any claims, but am merely leaving behind my thoughts. I think that the majority of the world does conceal this. Perhaps there is a different notion developing countries. One even has to wonder what is meant by *universal* here, if one defines it as "every single family on earth" then I would definitely say no, if one defines it as "the majority" then I would think to say yes. Perhaps one could separate by multiple attribute values. I think we need a little bit more information from Jay to know what exactly he is after. Again, I doubt if studies have been done...
I think this is a great question. +1.
I say it's right by santa claus's corner.

Biologically speaking incesto is bad but teaching and doing sex as early as possible is good. Obviously it helps the population grow more and faster. It sure is common in the animal world in which every creature begins very early to procreate. I just can't say if there's any **human** culture in which that's completely normal and accepted.
@bird Thanks for clarifying.
Another way I might ask this question is "Are there any cultures where masturbating no more hidden than picking your nose?"

**Notice:** Can we move this conversation somewhere else? Conversation is fine, but that's what the chat room is for. Comments are to help *improve* the question. Let's not use comment as mini chat rooms and forums. Thanks.

My question is based on many assumptions that were not widely accepted a few decades ago, and today are perhaps controversial, such as the suggestion that primitive life was not "solitary, poor, nasty, brutish, and short." I hope we don't get bogged down on these questions, but that may be impossible.
I also worry that I am again straddling the edge of the scope of this site.
See also: http://sexuality.stackexchange.com/questions/25/medical-detriments-benefits-of-masturbation
See also: http://sexuality.stackexchange.com/questions/81/how-much-masturbation-is-too-much

At the risk of speculation, could it be as simple as "Hey we had to many children, the extra ones are gonna die because we can't feed them (thus controlling the population), or our whole family will die, leading evolution to weed humans who have a tendency to create to many additional humans."?

Doesn't the side effects listed on the leaflet mention anything about this? Consult a doctor / gynecologist for more information on the possibility of such side effects. Also note that the menstrual cycle can be affected by [other things](http://women.webmd.com/tc/normal-menstrual-cycle-topic-overview): They include birth control pills, low body fat, losing a lot of weight, or being overweight. Stress or very hard exercise also can change your cycle. Pregnancy is the most common cause of a missed period. Perhaps she built up some stress because she was afraid to get pregnant? Hard to conclude.
You say "nope" and then specify the only thing you can't do is glide the foreskin. I'd say that counts as a technique.
It would be interesting to know of any studies on this. It's not something you can find out from chatting to friends.
@JayBazuzi: Don't worry, helping define the edges of the scope is *a good thing* to do.
How exactly can unprotected anal produce pregnancy?

The important here is the psychological dimension, and to evaluate how you (and others around you) feel about your masturbation habit. So that is what usually draws an limit over it. Because, you (or others) can feel bad about your habit faster than physical or other dimension.
Are you talking about physical or psychological detriments/benefits of masturbation or both? Because, most disadvantages that I know come from the psychological plane.

In the short term, there will be a [refractory period]( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Refractory_period) after orgasm, during which sex drive will drop off sharply. I'll leave the longer-term answer to those more knowledgable than I.
+1 for separating orgasm and ejaculation.
It is also not universally accepted that it exists, according to the same article.
@Tom: Because if there's semen anywhere aroung the vagina, including having come out of the anus, there's a risk of it entering the vagina and travelling far enough to reach and fertilize an egg.

In "Sexual Behavior in the Human Female" (page 205, heading "Low Frequencies and Sublimation") Kinsey spend some time examining the concept of sublimation.
His conclusion is that there is no evidence to support that sexual desire can be sublimated into other activities. (He notes that the existance sublimation cannot be outright disproved, but if it was in any way common, there should be evidence abundant in the tens of thousands of sexual histories he and his colleagues collected.)
Tensing and relaxing your Kegel muscles *during* intercourse may also work to delay orgasm. YMMV

I have received recommendations against using any kind of anaesthetic in combination with anal sex.
According to [netdoctor](http://www.netdoctor.co.uk/sexandrelationships/analsex.htm) "By numbing the anal skin there is a real risk of causing serious injury to the anal sphincter through over-vigorous thrusting."
@Coyote21 I'm interested in both. I clarified my question.

*How* you put on the condom also affect the sensation.
E.g. (on an uncircumcised penis, anyway) one may pull back the foreskin, apply condom partly up the shaft of the penis, then pull the foreskin back down again before unrolling the condom the rest of the way. -- This allows for more movement of the foreskin during intercourse, and a more "natural" feeling.
Correct. I know a couple who got pregnant through mutual masturbation, become some semen happened to land on her vulva.
I've removed the -1, because I don't think it was a deliberately poor question.
I don't believe this is unknown.
Don't vote down to below 0 for questions that are only somewhat relevant.
Ironicly, reducing sexual desire while on the pill means it's working as advertised regarding reducing pregnancy. Although it's not a particually good way of achieving this.
I'd like to know what is actually true about this as well.
I'm not really sure what you're asking here.
I'm suprised it's feet, agaisn't some of the others.
This seems to be a really good answer

Honestly, I'm not sure how I feel about the question as stated. I think this presupposes things that can't necessarily be assumed, in my opinion. Not only are the terms 'equally attractive' vague at best (and dubious at worst) but I also feel many people would argue that this is not true. I think this question is riddled with too many controversial assumptions at the moment. That said, I think maybe the base question of "Does availability of sexual partners (or lack there of) affect sexual crime?" To which I would just point to Ted Bundy and say "not necessarily".

Hmmm, I'm also a little confused by what the question is... is it about whether men or women find it easier to get sexual partners or is it about age gaps in relationships or is it about the impact of traditional porn pairings on sexuality?
Is this worded better now? I apreceate the feedback.

This reads to me as straying far more close than I'm comfortable with to "the reason men commit rape is that they can't find consenting partners; it's not their fault, they're just victims of their own hormones".

Not trying to justify sexual crime, it just how things are seem not acknowledged, so they are hard to improve. Sexual crime is really bad, thats one reason why I would like this to improve, it's almost not necessary. In England we have a "newspaper" that shows a mostly naked womman each week one page in. I'm not sugesting that just having a paper that showed an attractive naked man one page in would fix things, but something thinking along those lines. You know when Google used to auto-correct "she invented" to "he invented", nobody was sexist at Google, it was the internet they index that is.
Also. I'm saying I don't think it's got much to do with there hormones.

I think in the end, "most common" is just a matter of drawing a line. Once things are common enough, they're not usually considered fetishes, so the most common one is the most common thing that's still uncommon enough not to just be called "something not everyone's into". I still like the question, though; more data on what's out there is always great.

No proof that there's permanent desensitization, but also no proof that there isn't, right? So it's probably good to focus on the second part: judge for yourself whether dependence is an issue, and compensate if it is!

+1 for calling me out on the "fetish" term misuse. I was using it more as a "stuff I'm into" than the traditional definition. Maybe we should switch that up, I guess I'm just not sure what the term for it would be at that point. However, I would like a bit more credited source than a fetish board on the net. I am looking more for academic type information.
Tried to find the item that they are sourcing in the article, but the link doesn't seem to work... Do you have any more official sources for this info than Wikipedia?

@mrj You are correct. As I noted in my comment on one of the answers, I was more using it as a term for sexual interest than the proper definition. As soon as I figure out the term, I will switch it out for the correct. Thanks for calling me out on that.
Perhaps paraphilia is a better term for it? Maybe I'll start a discussion about it on the meta.

I think you could probably delete a lot of what you have after the actual questions and not lose much. You also left out the most obvious explanation for any differences between male and female gender roles: society.
Presumably there not gay but still. Does being seen as gay matter at all when considering things on the magnitude of having someone push their fist up your anus?

`The chances are that it's much harder for the man to find a sexual partner than for the woman.` <-- not sure how valid this claim is, or if it's even possible to gauge its validity. And I am positive that it changes based on demographics, geographics, etc.
Upon what do you base this assumption?
To me this seems like an anatomy question that has nothing to do with sexuality.

@Hugh that's true and I probably need to rephrase and/or reword it. What I meant is the classical technique of masturbation (sliding back and forth with the hands, also known as "5 vs 1") can be done with or without the foreskin, except that gliding makes it easier. Gliding in itself is a technique indeed but the point in doing it is only a way of achieving the same result you can do in at least one simple other way.
Rationalization is the base of all science and claiming that we need anecdotal experience isn't very rational at all. Other than that, very nice answer. Well structured.
Could you include a bit more detail on why lessening the testosterone level is a benefit?
Adding a link about testosterone: http://www.medicinenet.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=51013

Agreed, this is off topic for this site.

Regarding your second bullet: I don't think we want to go the route of "always safe" claims on this site...the only people who can make those claims are trained medical professionals, and you'd be pretty hard pressed to find one in most countries who will say anything is "always" safe.

Please avoid answers that are just "Yeah, I agree" or "here, let me tell you a personal story". They're not constructive, and are not likely to create an atmosphere of expert, research-level information that we strive to have.
-1 for not answering the question.
-1 - The question is about how to channel sexual desire into other things, not about whether or not polyamory is possible or acceptable. Feel free to ask a separate question about that.

This answer is all conjecture and opinion. I would like to see some outside research. I would also like to see you address the actual question - is the taboo universal, or are there cultures that do not hide their sexual experiences from their children?

@mrj It isn't a 'placebo' effect because it is hormonal, not psychological. The sugar pills are there so that you can simply remember to take one pill every day at the same time. The sugar pills enable you to keep up the routine, but they do not contain the dose that the real pills contain. The sugar pills do not 'cause' the bleeding - that is caused by the absence of the hormones present in the normal pills.
Anecdotal: a friend of mine skipped the rest period and went straight onto the next NuvaRing and it backfired miserably - she bled for a month straight.
I would like to see some sources cited here - we need some outside research. I'm downvoting for your use of 'perverts' to mean 'people who have fetishes' - the word has a very negative connotation
Should this question be edited to ask about a particular geographic region? Or should answers just include what the geographic / cultural scope is of any studies they cite?
@AbbyT.Miller I added links. I don't have access to subscription-only articles but the abstracts are available at the linked URLs.
I agree with Abby about your word choice and lack of supporting documents. Please back up your claims and experiences with formal research.
Could you please add references/citations that support your answer? Otherwise it's just a personal claim. We want to have well-supported, well-researched answers on this site.
Awesome, thank you!

-1 for not really answering the question. Providing (unsupported) arguments for and against concealing sexual expression from children does not address the OP's question about whether such concealment is a universal cultural value.

I'd also like to point out that there are different types of birth control pills, and the number of non-hormone-containing pills varies (depending on whether the birth control medication is monophasic, biphasic, or triphasic - and within each of those, between brands).
Reason number #20917 why anecdotes make bad Stack Exchange answers, and why we should not try to provide medical advice.

Technically speaking, a [vasectomy is reversible](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vasectomy#Vasectomy_reversal), though it's not meant to be thought of the same way as taking a pill, is super expensive, and will impact the ability to impregnate a woman even after the reversal surgery. Not a traditional "contraceptive" but it does technically count since it's a method that prevents fertilization.

There really isn't a question here, and the question is asked in a leading manner, with assumptions made that aren't backed up by references or real sources. As it is, this question is unanswerable and does not meet our quality standards.

I think that asking for generalizations about all "sex-restrive religions" (without even naming all the religions that you believe fall into this category) is a bad idea. Combined with your request to not summarize the reasons given in each religion's canon, it sounds like you're asking for speculation or personal belief. Furthermore, I would expect any such reason to change given the time and place in history being examined. I'm not 100% sure what you're asking, and I don't see a non-speculative answer to the question as it is worded.
One other note: If you include the phrase "there may not be a single definitive answer to this" in your question, there probably isn't one, which makes it not a good fit for the Stack Exchange model.

I think it's a good rule of thumb for answers to include a summary of the geographic and historic scope of the data presented (who did the research, where, and when) since I would assume that the answer to this question varies country to country, culture to culture, and how open/safe people feel discussing such things with researchers.

There isn't one "Christian church". There are many, and attitudes towards sex vary, and have varied over time. What's true for an Orthodox church in 1300 may not be true for an Episcopal church in 2012. I don't think there's any sort of specifically answerable question here.
An expert in sexuality wouldn't be the person to ask questions like this. This is a subject for Christianity or a sociological forum.

@Coyote21 It wasn't *my* question, it was the question asked by the OP at the top of the page. My point is that if your answer (the answer proper, not a comment to the answer) doesn't provide an explanation or argument to the OP's original point of interest, it shouldn't be posted as an answer at all. Your post, while related, is not an answer to the question. And since we are not a discussion board, it doesn't really belong.

Just a hunch, but I don't know that there's any data on the last part of your question (amount of sexual activity corresponding to the given failure rate). My understanding is that these failure rates are based on reported "perfect use" of each method. This means taking a contraceptive pill at exactly the same time every day with no medications that interfere with its effectiveness, following condom use instructions exactly. Most people don't use any method perfectly, and that's impossible to predict because there are so many additional factors (sobriety, type of activity, forgetfulness, etc).
Is your question "Is it possible to combine the rhythm method with the pill decrease chance of pregnancy?"
@Laura: Studies usually report numbers for both perfect and typical use; I'd be interested in this sort of data either way.
@JayBazuzi: That's essentially the second question, yes, but as the first question indicates, that's not the only thing I'm interested in.
The explanation isn't necessarily at all tied to sex; people also often like roller coasters, horror movies, sky-diving, and are drawn to watching accidents and disasters.
Also, if you were doing a study on this, presumably giving people a survey about how they used the birth control, why *wouldn't* you also ask them how often they had sex?

Nor is it universal. In many cases, a person that doesn't feel safe won't be interested in sex. While Maslow's put sex in the lowest tier of in his Hierarchy of Needs, he put sexual intimacy higher up.

Why not? I know you probably meant it as a joke, but some people might be into that. And for those who aren’t, urine is sterile so it probably wouldn’t be harmful; just potentially awkward. I’m not saying that for those people it isn’t lucky, but you haven’t substantiated the statement.

@Hugh Yes, it might be for *some*; not most people. As an example; Peeing inside a condom when you're not done could be really awkward, as you would have to hold up and go to the toilet or replace the condom. But really, I don't have to go into the details of all this. Answers don't have to list every single exception...

@emilfrojd: The problem is that broad phrases like "how do you handle" and "in a good way" leaves the user guessing what problem you are actually trying to solve.
